With the increase in technology usage and online learning during Fall 2020, we highly recommend you set up a dedicated space in the house for your child to learn. We have already seen so many creative, and innovative ways families have done this!

Anything from a table in the corner of the family office, the dining room table, or desk space in the child's room are great options. Here are the things we recommend for this learning space:

1. Quiet, or the option for headphones.

2. A clear, free space for them to write.

3. Free of food and beverages during learning time to avoid damaging spills.

4. Enough space away from siblings to prevent quarrels.

5. Separate from tempting toys and distractions. Even just facing their chair toward a window or wall so they cannot see their toys is a great option!

6. Decluttered as much as possible.

7. Access to a power source to charge their devices.

How has your family used their creativity to set up learning stations at home? Let us know in the comments!

Happy National Family Fun Month!

End summer with a 'BANG' and take some time to dedicate your creativity to making some fun family memories. Here are a few ideas to create a lasting memory this Family Fun Month:

1. Family at-home sleepover:
Indoor camping anyone?! Set up your family's sleeping bags on the floor together and have a "sleep over." Complete the night with a fun movie, popcorn, and flashlights!

2. Family game day:
Create a list of fun outdoor games such as baseball, water balloon fights, a chalk drawing contest and more. If there are enough people in the family, you can even form teams and compete against one another!

3. Family baking day!
Gather ingredients and have an old-fashioned baking day! Make a cake, cookies, or even a pie!

What fun plans is your family making this month? Let us know!

February is Black History Month!

This month, we are taking time to highlight influential African American citizens throughout history! Today's spotlight - Amy Sherald!

Amy Sherald is a modern-day American painter based in Baltimore, Maryland. She is widely known for her portrait paintings. With her art, she looks to broaden the genre of Historical Realism American Art by telling African-American stories represented in their own artistic tradition.

She is especially known for painting the official portrait of First Lady Michelle Obama for the National Portrait Gallery in Washington D.C.

To ready her full biography, click the link! üëâ
